repnme.cdata!:
Saint Lucia - Hurricane Tomas Emergency
            Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hurricane Tomas Emergency Recovery
            Project for Saint Lucia received a moderately satisfactory
            outcome rating with substantial risk to development outcome.
            The Bank received a satisfactory performance rating while
            the Borrower received a moderately satisfactory performance
            rating. The project had two restructurings. The first
            restructuring was in response to the mid-term review.
            Overruns and shortfalls were identified and as a result were
            cancelled and transferred to the Disaster Vulnerability
            Reduction Project (DVRP). Two structures were dropped and
            their funds were used to cover cost overruns on other parts
            of the project. A second restructuring extended the project
            closing date for another six months. The extension was
            needed to accommodate the completion of a key infrastructure
            facility for which after project effectiveness additional
            hydraulic surveys were identified to be critical to conduct
            prior to the investments; and to complete key geodetic and
            flood and hydraulic surveys that were necessary to support
            and inform proposed works under the DVRP that was under
            preparation. There were several lessons learned from this
            project including the following: (1) components designed to
            meet immediate liquidity needs are critical parts of
            post-disaster response, (2) climate resilient retrofitting
            entails comprehensive interventions that should be accounted
            for in initial designs, (3) projects, including emergency
            projects like the Hurricane Tomas Emergency Recovery Project
            (HTERP), that finance major rehabilitation of
            infrastructure, need to allow sufficient time for completion
            of work; three years is generally too short a time period,
            (4) initial estimates of rehab/retrofitting work costs need
            to be made carefully/conservatively to avoid major
            adjustments to the physical scope of the project down the
            road, (5) maintenance planning and budget needs to be part
            of rehabilitation work, (6) bank procurement procedures need
            to take better into account the limitations of the small
            island state context, and (7) preparation of rapid emergency
            projects face constraints, such as undefined scope of
            project activities and broad cost estimates due to lack of
            readily available data and pre-engineering studies.

repnme.cdata!:
Saint Lucia - Hurricane Tomas Emergency
            Recovery Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Hurricane Tomas
            Emergency Recovery Project for Saint Lucia is to support the
            recovery and reconstruction of the recipient in the
            aftermath of Hurricane Tomas. Negative impacts includes:
            acquisition of land; acquisition of private property; loss
            of assets; and displacement of persons. Compensation
            measures include: 1) provided prompt and effective
            compensation at full replacement cost for losses of assets
            attributable directly to the project; 2) calculation of
            compensation is based on market value; in determining market
            value the sale of property of similar characteristics with
            up to one year is used; 3) property valuations are very
            flexible and are always in favor the land owner. In
            determining the valuation of property location, number of
            dependencies and size of land are taken into consideration;
            and 4) interest should the payment to the affected landowner
            be delayed six percent interest is paid. This is
            substantially above interest rates paid by commercial Banks.
